entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 28 at 5:37AM EDT by NWS Mount Holly NJ
entry.summary:
There continues to be an increased risk of fire spread today. Relative humidity values this afternoon will drop to 20 to 30 percent across much of the area. Winds will remain light from the east to northeast around 5 to 10 mph, turning southeast in the afternoon with temperatures in the low to mid 60s and abundant sunshine. Vegetation remains very dry and could potentially become fuel for fires. These conditions will support the spread of any fires that ignite, which could quickly become difficult to control.
Outdoor burning is strongly discouraged. Be sure to properly extinguish or dispose of any potential ignition sources, including smoking materials such as cigarette butts. Refer to your state's forest fire management agency for more information on burn restrictions in your local area.
Relative humidity values recover to around 40 to 50 percent on Tuesday with southerly winds around 5 to 10 mph with gusts up to 15 mph. Regardless, burn restrictions may still be in place given the very dry conditions and lack of any recent rainfall. Refer to your state or local fire officials for more information.

entry.summary:
...A Red Flag Warning remains in effect for Monday from 11 AM to 6 PM MDT for portions of the Southeast Plains of Colorado...
...A Fire Weather Watch has been issued from Tuesday morning through Tuesday afternoon for portions of the Southeast Plains of Colorado...

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 28 at 4:25AM EDT by NWS Gray ME
entry.summary: Overnight rain and snow combining with temperatures that are now into the teens and 20s are creating concerns for slick driving conditions for the morning commute. While relatively warm ground temperatures will likely limit freeze potential, bridges and overpasses will be much more susceptible and may have some ice. Plan on slick driving conditions by giving yourself more time than usual or delaying travel until temperatures warm after sunrise.

entry.title: Fire Weather Watch issued October 28 at 1:55AM MDT until October 29 at 6:00PM MDT by NWS Goodland KS
entry.summary:
...FIRE WEATHER WATCH FOR MOST OF THE TRI-STATE AREA TUESDAY AFTERNOON...
.Gusty south-southwesterly winds ahead of a cold front are expected to create hazardous fire weather conditions Tuesday afternoon. Elevated thunderstorms could produce dry lightning east of highway 25 later in the afternoon. The cold front is expected to pass overnight, which will cause a wind shift from the southwest to northwest to occur.
The National Weather Service in Goodland has issued a Fire Weather Watch for very gusty winds and low relative humidity, which is in effect Tuesday afternoon.
* AFFECTED AREA...Fire Weather Zones 002 Rawlins, 003 Decatur, 004 Norton, 013 Sherman, 014 Thomas, 015 Sheridan, 016 Graham, 027 Wallace, 028 Logan, 029 Gove, 041 Greeley, 042 Wichita, 253 Kit Carson and 254 Cheyenne.
* WINDS...South 25 to 35 mph with gusts up to 60 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...As low as 15 percent.
* TEMPERATURES...Up to 85.
* LIGHTNING...10-20% chance of dry thunderstorms in the late afternoon, mainly east of highway 25.
* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly. Outdoor burning is not recommended.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Kit Carson County; Cheyenne; Rawlins; Decatur; Norton; Sherman; Thomas; Sheridan; Graham; Wallace; Logan; Gove; Greeley; Wichita

By Monday evening, a band of heavy snow is expected to develop between Anchorage and the western Kenai Peninsula. Slight deviations in the location of the band will dictate snowfall distributions. Highest snow accumulations are most likely to be north of Kasilof, whereas the greater Kachemak Bay area will be mostly rain. Stay tuned as we hone in the forecast.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Western Kenai Peninsula

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 27 at 10:36PM EDT by NWS Burlington VT
entry.summary: Overnight rain and snow combining with forecast temperatures dropping into the mid to upper 20s are creating concerns for slick driving conditions for the Monday morning commute. While ground temperatures in the Champlain Valley will likely limit freeze potential, bridges and overpasses will be much more susceptible and may have some ice. Plan on slick driving conditions by giving yourself more time than usual or delaying travel until temperatures warm after sunrise.

entry.title: Flood Watch issued October 27 at 3:20PM HST until October 28 at 6:00AM HST by NWS Honolulu HI
entry.summary:
...FLOOD WATCH FOR ALL HAWAIIAN ISLANDS THROUGH 6 AM HST MONDAY...
* WHAT...Flash flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible.
* WHERE...All the main Hawaiian islands.
* WHEN...Through late tonight.
* IMPACTS...Flood prone roads and other low lying areas may be closed due to elevated runoff and overflowing streams. Urban areas may receive more significant flooding and property damage due to rapid runoff.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - An upper low remains near the islands, and is producing unstable conditions within a very moist atmosphere. This will result in periods of moderate to locally heavy showers statewide through tonight. Rain that occurs over already saturated grounds could quickly lead to runoff and flash flooding.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued October 27 at 9:01PM EDT by NWS Melbourne FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...
St Johns River Near Astor affecting Volusia and Lake Counties.
.The Saint Johns River at Astor is forecast to continue a gradual decline through Moderate Flood Stage over the next 5 days. Residents and interests along the Saint Johns River should remain prepared for prolonged flood impacts.
For the St. Johns River...including Astor...Moderate flooding is forecast.
Additional information is available at www.weather.gov.
The next statement will be issued Monday morning at 1145 AM EDT.
* WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...St Johns River near Astor.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 3.5 feet, Canals have overflowed into yards. Homes on or near Wildhog, Bonnet and Snail roads become inaccessible with several inches of water inside homes along the river and canals. Docks at Astor Bridge marina and throughout Astor are completely submerged. Bartram Rd and Holiday Circle are inaccessible with yards completely submerged. Clair Street is inaccessible. Roads flooded in South Moon Fish Camp, docks and yards at condominiums on Juno Trail and water breaches the sea wall at Blair's Jungle Den.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:30 PM EDT Sunday the stage was 3.6 feet. - Bankfull stage is 2.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 8:30 PM EDT Sunday was 3.7 feet. - Forecast...The river, which is currently around 3.6 feet, is expected to continue a gradual decline through Moderate Flood Stage this week. - Flood stage is 2.3 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 27 at 7:34PM EDT by NWS Gray ME
entry.summary:
A very dry air mass and breezy conditions will combine with dead and dry fuels such as grass, leaves, and twigs to create the potential for uncontrolled fire spread across the southern half of New Hampshire on Monday. Relative humidity values will decrease to low levels of 20-25%. Winds will be lighter than Sunday, generally around 10 mph.
Extra caution should be taken to prevent wildfires. Always consult with fire officials before engaging in any open burning activities and comply with all applicable laws and regulations. Never leave an open fire unattended and always extinguish campfires completely before leaving.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 27 at 6:51PM EDT by NWS Mount Holly NJ
entry.summary:
There continues to be an increased risk of fire spread through Monday. Relative humidity values Monday afternoon will drop to 20 to 30 percent across much of the area. Winds will remain light from the east to northeast around 5 to 10 mph, turning southeast in the afternoon with temperatures in the low to mid 60s and abundant sunshine. Vegetation remains very dry and could potentially become fuel for fires. These conditions will support the spread of any fires that ignite, which could quickly become difficult to control.
Outdoor burning is strongly discouraged. Be sure to properly extinguish or dispose of any potential ignition sources, including smoking materials such as cigarette butts. Refer to your state's forest fire management agency for more information on burn restrictions in your local area.
Relative humidity values recover to around 40 to 50 percent on Tuesday with southerly winds around 5 to 10 mph with gusts up to 15 mph. Regardless, burn restrictions may still be in place given the very dry conditions and lack of any recent rainfall. Refer to your state or local fire officials for more information.

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued October 27 at 1:35PM AKDT until October 28 at 6:00AM AKDT by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Mixed precipitation, including freezing rain, snow, and rain expected. Total ice accumulations of a glaze to a few hundredths of an inch. Snow accumulations of up to 2 inches.
* WHERE...Bristol Bay from Dillingham north, including Koliganek and New Stuyahok.
* WHEN...From 7 PM Sunday to 6 AM AKDT Monday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Precipitation is expected to begin this evening as snow or a wintry mix before transitioning to a period of freezing rain overnight tonight into early Monday morning. In general, precipitation is expected to turn to all rain Monday morning. There continues to be some uncertainty as to exactly when the transition from freezing rain to rain will occur. If cold air holds on longer, expect ice totals closer to a few hundredths of an inch. Should temperatures warm faster, expect only a glaze of ice.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 27 at 1:34PM AKDT by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
A Bering Sea front will move ashore of Southwest Alaska coast this afternoon. Snow will spread from west to east across the Lower Kuskokwim Valley starting this evening and pick up in intensity overnight tonight. Snow will become lighter from west to east Monday morning while moderate snow will persist for locations near the Western Alaska Range. In general, expect most snow to fall from Crooked Creek southeastward to Lime Village where 3 to 6 inches are possible. Higher amounts are likely near the Western Alaska Range.
There is some mixed precipitation/freezing rain potential across the western most areas of the region, including Aniak with warmer air trying to nudge in aloft. The best chance at a period of mixed precipitation for western areas would be this evening before cooler air aloft works back in late tonight into Monday morning.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Lower Kuskokwim Valley

cap:parameter.value: MODERATE SNOW LIKELY ACROSS THE LOWER KUSKOKWIM VALLEY THIS EVENING THROUGH MONDAY MORNING

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued October 27 at 1:24PM PDT by NWS San Diego CA
entry.summary:
The South Coast AQMD has issued an air quality alert due to increased particle pollution from blowing dust. The air quality alert is in effect from 2 AM Monday to 9AM Tuesday.
In areas directly impacted by high levels of windblown dust, limit your exposure by remaining indoors with windows and doors closed and avoiding vigorous physical activity. Run your air conditioner or an air purifier. If temperatures allow, avoid using whole house fans or swamp coolers that bring in outside air.
Exposure to high particle pollution levels can cause serious health problems, including asthma attacks, heart and lung disease symptoms, and increased risk of respiratory infections. People with heart or lung diseases should follow their doctor's advice for dealing with episodes of unhealthy air quality. Children, older adults, and people with respiratory or heart disease should avoid prolonged exposure and strenuous activities when particle pollution levels are high.
To help minimize outdoor particle pollution levels: * Carpool, telecommute, reduce trips, or take public transportation * Slow down if driving on dirt roads * Stabilize loose soils
Levels of particle pollution can vary hour by hour and by location depending on wind conditions.
To view current and forecasted air quality levels, visit the South Coast Air Quality Management District website at aqmd.gov or download the mobile app at www.aqmd.gov/mobileapp. Additional details for this air quality alert may be available at www.aqmd.gov/advisory.
For the latest air quality forecasts and information, visit the website at aqmd.gov.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Coachella Valley

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued October 27 at 8:07AM MST by NWS Phoenix AZ
entry.summary:
The Arizona Department of Environmental Quality (ADEQ) has issued a PM-10 High Pollution Advisory for the Yuma area on Monday.
An episode of strong and gusty winds is forecast to generate widespread blowing dust that may result in local PM-10 concentrations that pose a health risk. Adverse health effects increase as air quality deteriorates.
Coarse particulate matter - also known as PM-10 - is an air contaminant that can aggravate heart and lung disease conditions, especially in older adults, children, and those with asthma. A decrease in physical activity is recommended.
Consolidate your travel, stabilize loose soils, slow down or avoid travel on dirt roads, reduce or eliminate fireplace use, and avoid using gas-powered lawn equipment.
For details on this High Pollution Advisory, visit the ADEQ internet site at www.azdeq.gov/forecast/yuma or call 602-771-2300.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Yuma

cap:parameter.value: PM-10 HIGH POLLUTION ADVISORY FOR THE YUMA AREA MONDAY
